en.sc1: Finally, consider the average case cost.
en.sc2: When record $i$ is processed, the number of times through the inner for loop depends on how far out of order the record is.
en.sc3: The inner for loop is executed once for each value greater than the value of record $i$ that appears in positions $0$ to $i-1$.
en.sc4: To calculate the average cost, we want to determine what is the average number of inversions will be for the record in position $i$.
en.sc5: This could be 0, or 1, or 2, or anything up to $i$. On average, it is $i/2$ positions out of order.
en.sc6: And since this had to be done for the records from $1$ to $n-1$, then we have the total cost as:
en.sc8: Therefore, the average case running time of insertion sort is $\theta(n^2)$.
